description: '''George Robert Crosby''' (August 23, 1913 – March 9, 1993) was an American [[jazz]] singer and bandleader, best known for his group the Bob-Cats, which formed around 1935. The Bob-Cats were a New Orleans Dixieland-style jazz octet. He was the younger brother of famed singer and actor [[Bing Crosby]]. On TV, Bob Crosby guest-starred in ''[[The Gisele MacKenzie Show]]''. He was also a regular cast member of ''[[The Jack Benny Program]],'' on both radio and television, taking over the role of bandleader after [[Phil Harris]]' departure. Crosby hosted his own afternoon TV variety show on [[CBS]], ''[[The Bob Crosby Show]]'' (1953–1957). Crosby received two stars on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]], for television and radio.
